dublin_core.dcvalue: The objective of the study was to examine the effectiveness of a customised personal digital assistant PDA as a cognitive aid for people with acquired brain injury using a randomised parallel group study The participants were 34 patients with acquired brain injury in a cognitive rehabilitation setting The experimental group used a customised PDA while the control group received care as usual paper and pencil aids Measurements were conducted at baseline T0 after 8 hours of training T1 after 16 hours of training T2 and at 5 month follow up T3 The main outcome was the attainment of individualised goals Both groups showed a significant increase in goal attainment GAS p Under 001 There were no significant differences between the groups at T1 or T2 on any of the other outcome measures It was concluded that the customised PDA was as effective as paper and pencil aids and may therefore serve as a useful alternative when choosing the optimal rehabilitation strategy for a patient
